questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not a biogenic amine?
questions.explanation:
Glycine is not a biogenic amine. It is an amino acid. Biogenic amines are made from amino acid precursors. They have a nitrogen containing amine 
(NH2) group. Unlike the amino acids, the biogenic amines lack a carboxyl (COOH) group. 
Norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine, serotonin and histamine are biogenic amines.

questions.question: Question 2: The main excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS are
questions.explanation:
Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS. It is responsible for 75% of the 
excitatory transmission in the brain. Glycine and GABA are the main inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS. Glycine is the main 
inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord. GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in 
the brain.

questions.question:
Question 3: 'A' delta fibers and 'C' fibers carry pain sensation. The neurotransmitter released by 'A' delta 
fibers is
questions.explanation: The neurotransmitter released by A delta fibers, which carry sharp pricking pain, is glutamate. The substance released by C fibers, which carry diffuse, chronic, burning pain is substance P.

questions.question: Question 4: The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is
questions.explanation:
The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is dopamine. 203 
Sold by @itachibot Reward pathway (mesolimbic pathway) connects the ventral tegmental area in the midbrain to the 
nucleus accumbens and limbic subcortical areas. This pathway is involved in reward behaviour, 
addiction and in psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia.

questions.question: Question 5: Dopamine beta hydroxylase converts dopamine to
questions.explanation:
Dopamine beta hydroxylase converts dopamine to norepinephrine. Vitamin C is required as a 
cofactor for the enzyme.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of these is not a dopaminergic pathway?
questions.explanation:
Corticostrial pathway is not a dopaminergic pathway. The corticostrial pathway is the primary input pathway for the basal ganglia which uses glutamate 
as the neurotransmitter. Important dopaminergic pathways are: • Mesolimbic pathway - Increased activity responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia. • Mesocortical pathway - Decreased activity responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia. • Nigrostriatal pathway - Decreased activity causes extrapyramidal symptoms. • Tuberoinfundibular pathway - Decreased activity causes increase in prolactin. 204 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Find the incorrect match.
questions.explanation: Basal forebrain complex (nucleus basalis of Meynert) is rich in acetylcholine. A loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert is seen in alzheimer's disease.

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient with involuntary jerking and writhing movements is diagnosed with Huntington's 
disease. Loss of which of the following is responsible for hyperkinetic symptoms in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The hyperkinetic feature of Huntington's disease is due to the loss of intrastriatal GABAergic and 
cholinergic neurons. The loss of the GABAergic pathway (which is an inhibitory pathway) to the 
globus pallidus external segment and loss of cholinergic neurons in many parts of the brain 
decreases inhibition, causing the hyperkinetic feature of the disease to develop. Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder with multiple CAG 
repeats. The abnormal gene responsible for the disease is located on chromosome 4.

questions.question:
Question 9: An infant develops features of botulism following honey intake. This toxin blocks 
neuromuscular transmission by which of the following mechanisms?

options.a: Prevents release of Ach at presynaptic membrane
options.b: Opening of calcium channels at the presynaptic membrane
options.c: Prevents the binding of Ach at the postsynatic membrane
options.d: Prevents the action of Ach at the postsynaptic membrane

questions.explanation:
Botulinum toxin prevents the release of Ach at the presynaptic membrane. Botulinum toxins A, B, and E are toxic to humans. They cleave components of SNARE - a complex 
of proteins necessary for the exocytosis of acetylcholine. Toxins A and E cleave SNAP-25 whereas 
toxin B cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP) also known as synaptobrevin. Cleavage of SNARE proteins prevents the release of acetylcholine as the vesicles containing Ach 
are unable to bind to the presynaptic membrane. 205 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A farmer presents with difficulty swallowing and jaw tightening. He gives a history of getting 
his finger jammed in the rustic gate a few days ago. He gives no history of previous tetanus 
immunization. After evaluation, he was diagnosed with tetanus. The release of which of the 
following neurotransmitters is affected by the toxin responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Tetanus toxin affects the release of GABA. Tetanus toxin escapes normal lysosomal degradation and crosses the synapse to the GABA-ergic 
presynaptic inhibitory interneuron terminals. The toxin blocks the release of inhibitory 
neurotransmitters (glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid) across the synaptic cleft. This blockage 
of the inhibitory neurotransmitters causes spastic paralysis.

questions.question:
Question 11: The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is  
.
questions.explanation:
The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is glycine. Renshaw cell is an inhibitory interneuron which is activated by collaterals from spinal motor 
neurons. Renshaw cell terminates on the cell body of the same and other spinal motor neurons. It 
reduces or stops the discharge of the motor neuron by releasing glycine.

questions.question:
Question 12: 200 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following neurotransmitters is increased during REM sleep?
questions.explanation:
Acetylcholine increases during REM sleep. In REM sleep, there is increase in acetylcholine and decrease in norepinephrine and serotonin. 
The reverse of this pattern leads to wakefulness. Levels of neurotransmitte 
r Neurotransmitters in REM sl 
eep Acetylcholine 
Increased Serotonin 
Decreased Norepinephrine

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the wrong match?

options.c: Sympathetic post ganglionic fibres - release noradrenaline
options.d: Sweat glands - innervated by sympathetic adrenergic fibres

questions.explanation:
Sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibres (not adrenergic fibres). Pre-ganglionic fibres of the sympathetic nervous system, pre-ganglionic fibers of the 
parasympathetic nervous system and post-ganglionic parasympathetic fibres release acetylcholine. Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres release noradrenaline in most of the sites, except in certain 
places such as sweat glands, piloerector muscles and blood vessels in some skeletal muscles where 
acetylcholine is released.

questions.question: Question 14: Which part of the basal ganglia is the neurotransmitter glutamate secreted from?
questions.explanation:
Projections from subthalamic nucleus to globus pallidus are glutaminergic. Neurotransmitters secreted by various regions of basal ganglia: • Substantia nigra pars compacta = dopamine • Substantia nigra pars reticulata = GABA • Subthalmic nuclei = glutamate • Corpus striatum to globus pallidus = GABA • Intrastriate neurons = acetylcholine • Globus pallidus = GABA Diagrammatic representation of the principal connections of the basal ganglia. Acetylcholine is the transmitter produced by interneurons in the striatum. 207 
Sold by @itachibot (SNr : substantia nigra pars reticulata; SNc: substantia nigra pars compacta; STN: Subthalamic 
nucleus ; GPe: globus pallidus externa ; GPi: Globus pallidus interna).

questions.question: Question 15: All of the following are excitatory neurotransmitters except:
questions.explanation: Serotonin is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. Acetylcholine, glutamate and norepinephrine are excitatory neurotransmitters.

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following is not true about serotonin receptor? 201 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
5-HT2C receptor agonists increase satiety (state of being fed beyond capacity). Important serotonin receptors: • 5-HT2A receptors mediate platelet aggregation and smooth muscle contraction. • 5-HT3 receptors are present in the GIT and the area postrema and are related to vomiting. • 5-HT4 receptors are present in the GIT and brain. They facilitate secretion and peristalsis in 
GIT. • 5-HT6 and 5-HT7 are distributed throughout the limbic system. Note: All are G protein coupled receptors except 5-HT3 which is a ligand gated ion channel 
receptor.

questions.question: Question 17: Serotonin is present in highest concentration in
questions.explanation:
Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT) is present in highest concentration in platelets and in the 
gastrointestinal tract, where it is found in the enterochromaffin cells and the myenteric plexus. It 
is also found within the brain stem in the midline Raphe nuclei. Note: The precursor of serotonin is tryptophan. 208 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Which statement regarding the NMDA receptor is incorrect?
questions.explanation:
NMDA receptor permits passage of Ca2+ and other cations (Na+), not of chloride. Glutamate is the agonist for NMDA receptor. Glycine binding to the NMDA receptor is essential 
for the receptor to respond to glutamate. NMDA receptors are present on hippocampal neurons. Note: GABA and glycine receptors act by increasing Cl- conductance. 209 
Sold by @itachibot Sensory Receptors
